Lake Denman

The Ruby Koans

Jim Weirich and Joe O’Brien over at edgecase have done a good job programming The Ruby Koans, the challenging and fun path to Ruby enlightenment.

Imagine that you are student in search of the enlightened path. The Ruby Koan is your Sensei. You must follow the rules that have been placed before you.

The Ruby Koans is mostly full of short, educating, and interesting problems. Do not, however, expect to solve The Ruby Koans in the length of a day. Mastering the Ruby Koans may take you several days to complete.

Just relax and take your time while focusing on the challenges at hand. irb has proven to be an essential tool while learning the behavior of ruby. ri came in handy as I needed to look up documentation from time to time. Here comes a look at a the behavior of the Ruby Koan.

The Sensei Speaks

Lets say that you have a brand new copy of The Ruby Koans. Run the first koan by changing into the directory and running rake.

Examine the output below:

    ruby_koans$: rake
    (in /Users/lake/Projects/ruby_koans)
    cd koans
    /opt/ruby-enterprise-1.8.6-20090201/bin/ruby path_to_enlightenment.rb

    Thinking AboutAsserts
      test_assert_truth has damaged your karma.

    You have not yet reached enlightenment ...
    <false> is not true.

    Please meditate on the following code:
    ./about_basics.rb:10:in `test_assert_truth'
    path_to_enlightenment.rb:27


    mountains are merely mountains

The Ruby Koan Lifecycle

The Ruby Koan begins when rake is typed at the prompt: the :default rake task is set to :walk_the_path. The important Rakefile excerpt is below:

# ...
task :default => :walk_the_path

task :walk_the_path do
  cd 'koans'
  ruby 'path_to_enlightenment.rb'
end
#...

It starts by telling ruby to execute the path_to_enlightenment.rb file. Notice that there are 24 files being required in the path_to_enlightenment.rb file. These files define the koans that are used for enlightenment.

After all the files are required, the END block from the edgecase.rb file is run. Let’s take a look at that END code block.

Beginning at the END

Find the END block at the end of edgecase.rb (it’s at the bottom and highlighted.)

Here is one line example of using the END keyword:

$ ruby -e "END { puts 'But I didn\'t shoot the deputy' }; puts 'I shot the sheriff'"
I shot the sheriff
But I didn't shoot the deputy

Path to Enlightenment

The path_to_enlightenment.rb file require’s the about_basics.rb file first and, while requiring, fails at line 10.

Notice line 4 from path_to_enlightenment.rb? The edgecase.rb file is required which sets up a few necessary components:

  • FillMeInError class that inherits from StandardError
  • Methods for default answers
  • A Sensei class responsible for accumulating and reporting the koan results is defined
  • A Koan class responsible for running the koans
  • A END code block that runs when the script exits
